Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: The Effects of Nature Tourism as a Development Strategy on Poverty and Inequality: The Cases of Namibia and Mozambique

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Persistent poverty and rising inequality are pressing concerns within Sub-Saharan Africa. The relationship between international trade and inequality has come under increased scrutiny as African countries continue to liberalize their economies and adopt export-based growth strategies, mainly focusing on agricultural exports. Despite rapid economic liberalization, however, many African countries have been unable to export themselves out of poverty via the agricultural sector. Governments are looking increasingly to tourism exports as a source of growth. Yet there is little empirical evidence on how nature tourism (wildlife and nature viewing, safari hunting, and fishing) impacts rural development. This CAREER project will examine how nature tourism affects poverty and inequality in Namibia and Mozambique at the regional, community, and household levels, while also accounting for diversity between and within countries. Namibia is considered a pioneer of using community-based nature tourism as a rural development strategy, while Mozambique has more recently embarked on the promotion of nature tourism and community conservancy programs. The researcher will investigate these development strategies in a variety of ways. Quantitative research will be used to examine relationships between nature-based tourism and the quality of life of nearby local populations. For example, the investigator will study whether there is a relationship between households' incomes and their distance from parks. Qualitative research will build on this, and investigate the detailed effects of economic changes on people's lives. The investigator will conduct surveys and interviews with residents in ten communities located near sites of nature tourism, to see how tourism is affecting local livelihoods and the social structures of communities. This project expects to contribute to new knowledge of the benefits and risks associated with the promotion of nature tourism as a development strategy in emerging economies.

The proposed study (1) investigates how well economic theories of trade explain the effects of tourism on poverty and inequality in rural regions; (2) assesses the effects of nature tourism on poverty and inequality, while accounting for environmental, economic, and cultural diversity within southern Africa; (3) explicitly investigates how experiences of rural development strategies are influenced by community organization and empowerment; and (4) uses an iterative, mixed methodology--integrating qualitative and quantitative research techniques--to explore the impacts of export-led rural development strategies at the national, regional, and local scales. The study involves close collaboration with the University of Namibia (UNAM) and the Pedagogical University of Mozambique (UP). Students from both universities will gain valuable exposure to social science research, and those from UP--a teachers college--will be able to incorporate this research into K-12 curricula. The results of the study will be made available to UNAM and UP for use in their training modules and classroom instruction. In addition, the results of the analysis will be integrated into the investigator's own future classroom teaching on African economic development.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project investigated nature tourism’s effects on poverty and inequality in sub-Saharan Africa. Nature tourism projects, and the development policies that support them, aim to promote both conservation and development goals. By encouraging tourists to visit and view natural landscapes and wildlife, they hope to generate income for local communities, while also supporting the preservation of endangered wildlife and their habitats. Governments in many countries have set up Integrated Conservation and Development Projects (ICDPs) with these goals in mind. Though some nature tourism projects involve licensed hunting of big game, this study focused on other cases, in which tourism for animal viewing, rather than hunting, is encouraged. This study investigated the cases of Namibia and Mozambique, each of which has promoted ICDPs. In each country, the study examined two parks or protected areas. Residents in a total of eight communities were surveyed and interviewed multiple times over the course of this longitudinal study.

Arguments in favor of ICDPs commonly invoke economic incentives and outcomes. It is argued that such schemes will increase income, and reduce poverty, in the areas where they operate. And it is argued that these increases in income will encourage compliance with the ICDP project, aiding associated conservation goals. In a series of research articles, the Principal Investigator and her international collaborators examined to what extent economic effects are actually present. The project found economic benefits of ICDPs in some, but not all, studied areas. Even in areas where there were noticeable benefits to local incomes, there was an absence of predicted community-wide benefits, such as improvements in infrastructure. In areas where ICDPs have generated some economic benefits, social and economic inequality increased. However, higher levels of local-level inequality was also associated with greater agency in voicing dissatisfaction and suggesting improvements for IDCPs among residents living near parks and protected areas

Beyond these basic findings, four other general points are notable. First, we found significant social effects of ICDPs, which varied by area. For example, where tourism contributed to economic development, we found some conflict between local residents with rising incomes and local elites over the control of resources. Secondly, the research identified important contextual factors that worked together with economic incentives. For example, high levels of social cohesion and strong attachment to where one lives contributes to wider acceptance of nature tourism, even when it fails to bring about improved quality of life for the vast majority of residents. Thirdly, the project's findings indicate that tourism employment can have mitigating effects on gender inequality. Fourthly, local-level concerns about ICDPs, and parks more generally, involve non-monetary dimensions of development such as justice and fairness. Findings suggest that some of the strongest local criticisms of ICDPs center on the perception that park management prioritizes animals over people. For example, findings indicate that people living near parks or protected areas often view restrictions on hunting small game, such as rabbits, as disrespectful to their way of life and a violation of their dignity.

The project has had broad impact in advancing desired societal outcomes, such as strengthening relationships between US and foreign institutions, increasing the involvement of underrepresented groups in scientific research, and improving education and teacher development in geography and spatial sciences.
